qas.question: In what year did Athanasius return to his episcopal capitol?
In what year did Emperor Constantius die?
How did George of Cappadocia die in prison?
Were the Arians united in their oppostion?

answers.text: The Arians no longer presented an unbroken front

qas.question: What happened to the usurping bishop, George?

answers.text: An obscure presbyter of the name of Pistus

qas.question: When did Athanasius re-enter the capitol?
In what year was Emperor Constantius born?
How did George of Cappadocia die outside of prison?

context: <a5_0>The Arians no longer presented an unbroken front<a5_0/> to their orthodox opponents. The Emperor <b11_0>Constantius<b11_0/>, who had been the cause of so much trouble, died 4 November, <a3_0>361<a3_0/> and was succeeded by <a0_0><a6_0><b10_0>Julian<b10_0/><a6_0/><a0_0/>. The proclamation of the new prince's accession was the signal for a pagan outbreak against the still dominant Arian faction in Alexandria. George, the usurping Bishop, was <a7_0>flung into prison and <a4_0><b13_0>murdered<b13_0/><a7_0/><a4_0/>. <a8_0>An obscure presbyter of the name of <a1_0>Pistus<a8_0/><a1_0/> was immediately chosen by the Arians to succeed him, when fresh news arrived that filled the orthodox party with hope. An edict had been put forth by Julian permitting the exiled bishops of the "Galileans" to return to their "towns and provinces". Athanasius received a summons from his own flock, and he accordingly re-entered his episcopal capitol on <a9_0>22 February, <a2_0><b12_0>362<b12_0/><a9_0/><a2_0/>.
